instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ssd blown part?
threads.message:
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> here that was given to me with "not seeing hard drive" I test with good known ssd and board works perfectly. 

I take a look at the ssd under the scope and notice this blown component -(see pic) 
All components around this area seem to short to ground. 

You can see the black component bulging in 2 places where it has blown, do we know what this is. Can it be replaced? 

[ATTACH]60921[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ssd blown part?
threads.message:
Is C7S the marking code?
I didn't find any information on it.
You can try to search adding "SMD code", "DFN-8" or both on Google.

Looks like a dual MOSFET (connected in parallel), or some voltage regulator.
Remove it and check for short on SSD side.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ssd blown part?
threads.message:
It looks more like C78, Googled the nuts off it and cant find anything really, 

I can replace the drive for Â£15 so its probably not worth the hassle.
